newsitem.title: USA: BOXING-"FIGHT DOCTOR" SAYS FOREMAN'S SUCCESS IS DANGEROUS.
newsitem.headline: BOXING-"FIGHT DOCTOR" SAYS FOREMAN'S SUCCESS IS DANGEROUS.

text.p: It's not that the "Fight Doctor" hates George Foreman personally. Ferdie Pacheco hates the example the 48-year-old fighter is setting for other older boxers who have been tempted to risk their lives by going back to taking punches for pay.

"Foreman's opening the barn door to all these ex-champs to come back," said Pacheco, who dubbed himself "The Fight Doctor" in the days when he ministered to Muhammad Ali when the great champion ruled the heavyweight world. That was before Pacheco quit Ali's corner after failing to convince him to retire.
"When George came back and got millions, they decided they'd come back for some big paydays," Pacheco said Thursday in an interview from his home in Tampa, Florida.

Foreman, 75-4, is a slight underdog in the fight against the 31-year-old Savarese (36-0). If Foreman, who will be paid about $4 million compared to Savarese's $500,000, wins he can be expected to angle for millions more against the winner of the June 28 Evander Holyfield-Mike Tyson rematch.

Considering the quality of his recent opponents, Foreman hardly qualifies for a title fight. That's particularly obvious in light of his refusals of mandatory fights -- most likely because he thought they would be too tough -- after winning two titles in 1994, leading to his being stripped of his crowns. He has fought twice since.
And Savarese's opponents have been less than formidable.
Pacheco used Ali and Sugar Ray Robinson, generally considered the best pound-for-pound fighter ever, as examples of the dangers of older men fighting.

Before he died, Robinson suffered acutely from the effects of taking all those punches over a very long career. And Ali sufferes from Parkinson's Syndrome, which very noticeably affects his motor skills and speech.
"No one can take a look at Sugar Ray Robinson and Ali and not see that you're gonna pay the bill eventually, all the tissue you're damaging," Pacheco said.
"George (Foreman) has the same brain as everyone else. You jar a brain that is soft Jell-O in a hard cover, you're gonna break little blood vessels," Pacheco said.
"Some serious people have beat him up," said Pacheco, referring to Foreman's tough fights in recent years against Evander Holyfield, Alex Stewart and Michael Moorer.

Knocking out the congenitally inattentive Moorer in the 10th round in 1994 with a sledgehammer right hand that arrived with all the speed of a dirigible -- making Foreman the oldest heavyweight champion ever -- may have been the worst thing for Foreman and other older fighters as far as Pacheco is concerned.

Pacheco, who works as a boxing commentator for Showtime cable television -- a rival to HBO, which employs Foreman in a similar capacity -- says he was opposed to Foreman coming out of retirement in 1987, "not because I didn't think he could do well but because I thought he could succeed.
"He had that big punch, and I thought he would do okay and it would only encourage other old fighters to come back."

The list of former fighters who have returned to the ring or are considering comebacks include 47-year-old former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes, who is admittedly fighting just for the money 24 years after he turned professional.

Former cruiserweight champion Dwight Muhammad Qawi is coming back at 44, saying, "if (Foreman) can do it, I can. George has influenced and inspired me." And Saoul Mamby, soon to be 50, is also returning.

Then there is Sugar Ray Leonard, 41 next month, who embarrassed himself in a loss last month to Hector Camacho and says he will fight again. Roberto Duran, one of the greatest lightweights ever, is still fighting in his 40s.
And, Pacheco says, if a promoter dangles some money in front of a lot of other old fighters they would jump through the ropes faster than Don King could say, "Only in America."
"All of this is singularly due to George's big punch," said Pacheco, who feels boxing commissions should deny licenses to older fighters on grounds of age alone, regardless of their apparent health.
"Boxing, if it were well done would be exhilarating," Pacheco said. "But it's run like a banana republic. If you got the money and the relatives you got the fight."
And the potential brain damage.
